details.description:
Blockchains, or ‘distributed ledgers’, are a new area of distributed technology that are generating a lot of interest. They have the potential to become an important component of our global data infrastructure. This session will cover the basics of the technology, review use cases and applications, and consider how blockchains may link into our global data infrastructure. We will also consider how blockchains will need to grow and scale over time, potential privacy implications for personal data, and findings from the ODI’s experimentation in building a blockchain system for data storage.

<< Back to full schedule

Suitable for

Non-technical audiences who seek to understand the potential of distributed ledger technology in commercial or policy contexts. If you’ve heard the blockchain hype, but aren’t sure how (or if) the technology is relevant to you, then this session will answer your questions.

About the trainer: James Smith

James is passionate about using web technology and open data to make a better future for everyone, with a particular focus on the environmental and social benefits that can be created.

Pushing forward the state of the art in open data technology, James leads the ODI’s Labs programme and the software team which delivers software projects across the ODI.

James has been a software developer for over 17 years working in a variety of industries including biometrics, flight simulation and visual effects. He obtained a PhD from the University of Surrey creating new 3D graphics algorithms.
